title.narrative: SWE-2011-115 Good governing of rural electrification processes in Eastern Africa The importance of formal and informal institutions
SWE-2011-115 Good governing of rural electrification processes in Eastern Africa The importance of formal and informal institutions

description.narrative: The general aim is to identify and analyze the main (formal and informal) institutional requirements needed for a successful wider adoption, adaptation and diffusion of small and medium-scale renewable energy technologies in rural areas of Tanzania and Mozambique. By studying several previous and on-going electrification projects in the two countries, we seek to answer the questions: can differences in formal/informal institutions, at local/regional/national level, explain the varying degrees of success for the projects? In the project we pay particular attention to gender biases and the role of local participation. The main methods are stakeholder and expert interviews, participatory observation, and document analysis. The project includes collaborations with researchers and stakeholders in Tanzania and Mozambique.

The general aim is to identify and analyze the main (formal and informal) institutional requirements needed for a successful wider adoption, adaptation and diffusion of small and medium-scale renewable energy technologies in rural areas of Tanzania and Mozambique. By studying several previous and on-going electrification projects in the two countries, we seek to answer the questions: can differences in formal/informal institutions, at local/regional/national level, explain the varying degrees of success for the projects? In the project we pay particular attention to gender biases and the role of local participation. The main methods are stakeholder and expert interviews, participatory observation, and document analysis. The project includes collaborations with researchers and stakeholders in Tanzania and Mozambique.
